interview.question: What happened in the first set? Obviously not your finest hour.
interview.answer: I don't think not my finest two and a half hours. No, I wasn't putting anything on the ball the whole match. I was playing a little bit tight. I sort of wasn't hitting freely. I was just letting him get in the points and get in the match.

interview.question: You did have stretches of playing reasonably well, I thought.
interview.answer: But never the right way. He gave me a lot of mistakes. And it was always similar sort of the third set. I had a lot of break chances in the third set, but I was always missing the first or second ball. Then I just started overthinking a little bit too much.

interview.question: And the second serve on the set point in the fourth set, just another day at the office?
interview.answer: That's how I know how to serve. I hope that's how it always goes.

interview.question: Did that affect you at all, the fact that you hit a let on the previous serve?
interview.answer: No. I was thinking to go wide, but I've been doing this serve the whole time. I haven't really been double‑faulting. I double‑faulted maybe early in the game, but on the deuce side. I wasn't double‑faulting at all on that side.

interview.question: Do you blame any of the erratic play on the pretty windy conditions?
interview.answer: No, the wind wasn't that bad, as bad as it seems. It was actually pretty okay to play. I just wasn't swinging freely, and then just the wind seem a lot worse than it is. My legs weren't moving, my arm wasn't moving, so the margin for error when I was swinging through the ball was much smaller.

interview.question: How do you explain not moving the arms?
interview.answer: First match. Just looking to get better and better. I think I played better against Giraldo last year in US Open, but I think it was same of the sort of the same situation. Then I came out better and better and better by the match. So happy to get through and trying to make it better.

interview.question: So it's Rosol or Jamie Baker.
interview.answer: I played Jamie I think three times, three weeks in a row, in futures in Bangkok. Three weeks in a row I played him. I think semis all three weeks. I won twice and lost once.

interview.question: Rosol is he anything but a guy that had one phenomenal performance?
interview.answer: That's not my place to comment. We'll see about that in two days.

interview.question: And what did you think of him today? Steady at certain times.
interview.answer: He's steady. He doesn't move that great. He needs time. That's why I felt I let him into it quite often, because I'm normally pretty good when I get ahead in the point making the guy go from side to side. Guys like Ferrer that defend really well I struggle with a bit more. I wasn't able to get him going, and that's the thing. I was letting him into the game. That's why I was a bit disappointed with, well, not just that part but many parts of the match.

interview.question: Trying to incorporate a few new things into your game this year. I guess you weren't too successful with that today.
interview.answer: No. The only thing I incorporated is winning the match and getting by and trying to be better.
